III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section Sufficiency of staff.
Description (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Allegation #1
The youth does not feel safe at the facility because they are not
allowed to sleep with their light on and the youth was previously
assaulted by other youth.
Allegation #2
Staff allow youth to fight before intervening.
Investigation Allegation 1:
Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 6/24/2025.
Complainant did not provide any additional information.
Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 6/24/2025.
COO was also present via speakerphone. Director reported Youth
A does well at the facility. Director denied knowledge of Youth A
feeling unsafe at the facility. Director reported Youth A messes
around with other youth and at times will get into altercations with
them. The youth are redirected and separated when this occurs.
Director denied Youth A sustaining any marks or injuries from
these types of incidents since an incident of having a carpet burn
which was previously investigated. Director denied awareness of
Youth A wanting to sleep with a light on and being told no.
Director denied knowledge of Youth A feeling unsafe at the facility
for any reason.
Case Manager was interviewed via telephone on 6/24/2025. Case
Manager denied having significant concerns regarding Youth A’s
care and safety in the facility. Case Manager denied awareness
of any concerns with Youth A wanting a light on at night or Youth
A not feeling safe at the facility for any reason. Case Manager
reported Youth A has history of arguing with other youth stating he
is often the instigator. Case Manager reported Youth A has
expressed being afraid of objects such as large tree branches or a
stomp in the snow he thought was a person. Case Manager
denies Youth A expressing fear of any staff or items specific to the
facility.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/17/25.
Youth A reported getting along with most of the other youth at the
2

facility except sometimes he fights with Youth B. Youth A reported
when they start to argue staff will tell us to stop and separate them
from each other. Youth A reported he sleeps good at the facility
and has a light he can turn on if he wants to. Youth A reported he
does not feel safe at the facility because about a month ago there
was a storm and the power went out.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/17/25.
Youth B reported sometimes he gets along with Youth A but
sometimes they fight. Youth B reported Youth A will try to argue
with him and Youth B will try to walk away. Youth B reported
when they start to argue staff will ask them to stop. Youth B
denied hearing Youth A say he is afraid of anything.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/17/25.
Staff 1 denied Youth A ever expressing not feeling safe at the
facility. Staff 1 reported Youth A will get into it with Youth B often
but other times they get along well and will play together. Staff 1
reported if they start to argue staff will redirect and separate them
if they need to. Staff 1 reported Youth A has a tendency to pick on
others and try to agitate them by teasing them. Staff 1 reported
staff allow Youth A to have a light on in his room and he keeps it
on overnight. Staff 1 reported Youth A is doing well at the facility
and requires less redirection than he used to.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/17/25.
Youth A is allowed to keep his light on in his room overnight and
has seen him do so during her shift. Staff 2 denied hearing Youth
A express not feeling safe at the facility. Staff 2 reported Youth A
will get into altercations with Youth B by arguing back and forth
and calling each other names when one wants to play a certain
way that the other does not. Staff 2 reported when this occurs
staff will verbally redirect and physically get in between Youth A
and Youth B if needed. Staff 2 reported they will keep them in
different areas as well to avoid conflict. Staff 2 could not recall a
time these interventions failed and Youth A and Youth B physically
fought.
Allegation 2
Interviews:
The below interviews occurred as indicated under allegation
1.
During his interview Director reported Youth A messes around
with other youth and gets into altercations with them. When this
occurs the youth are redirected and separated.
3

Case Manager denied concerns with staff not intervening when
youth get into altercations.
Youth A reported when he starts to argue with his peer staff will
tell them to stop and separate them from each other.
Youth B reported if him and his peer start to come at each other
like they will fight staff will get in between them so they cannot
fight.
Staff 1 reported if youth start to argue staff will redirect and
separate them if they need to.
Staff 2 reported when the youth argue staff will verbally redirect
and when needed will physically get in between them. If needed
they will also keep them in different areas to avoid conflict.
Documentation Reviewed:
• Incident Reports (19) regarding Youth A from 2/2025-
6/2025. IRs document Youth A showing verbal and
physically aggressive behavior to other youth, not following
directives, and destroying property. One IR dated 3/3/2025
states Youth A refused to go to school. Four IRs dated
3/25/25, 3/26/25, 3/27/25, and 4/5/25 document Youth A
refused an offered meal.
• Physical Aggression Policy and Procedure states the
approach to reducing and eliminating physical aggression
is validating the reality of the youth, showing empathy and
addressing the behavior.
Analysis There are no rule violations established regarding these
allegations. There is no evidence or reports of staff in the facility
failing to intervene when youth get into altercations or that Youth A
feels unsafe for any reason within the facility’s control.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section Program Statement
Description (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety,
and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
4

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A youth has missed 10 days of school due to staff not waking the
youth up in time.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 6/24/2025.
Complainant did not provide any additional information.
Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 6/24/2025.
COO was also present via speakerphone. Director denied Youth A
missing as many as 10 days of school nor it being multiple days in
a row. Director reported if a youth refuses to get up for school a
supervisor is notified and efforts to get the youth up continue.
Director reported usually the facility informs the school a youth will
be absent.
Case Manager was interviewed via telephone on 6/24/2025.
Case Manager denied ability to confirm days of school missed for
Youth A since being placed at the facility and was not aware of
school absences being a concern for Youth A.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/17/25.
Youth A reported he misses school all the time. Youth A was not
able to say when he last missed school, how many days he
missed, or why he misses school. Youth A would not respond to
questions at this time of the interview.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/17/25.
Youth B reported there are days Youth A will not get up for school
and staff tell him to get up. Youth B did not know what happens
after staff try to wake up Youth A and could not recall which staff
try to wake up Youth A.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/17/25.
Staff 1 reported it is a struggle to get Youth A up for school. Staff 1
reported they ask him to get up several times each morning and
there have been times he did not get up and missed school due to
that. Staff 1 denied it being 10 times, stating that sounds high.
Staff 1 reported an incident report is completed if a youth refuses
to go to school.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/17/25.
Staff 2 reported she has heard Youth A has missed some school
however was not aware of how many times.
Documentation Reviewed:
5

• Residential Treatment Overview; Reporting and
Documentation of Critical Incidents. School Absences are
not listed as an incident in need of an incident report.
• Student Attendance History Report regarding Youth A
reflects 8 unexcused absences, 2 unexcused tardies, and 6
excused tardies from February 2025-June 2025.
• Incident Reports (IR) (19) regarding Youth A from 2/2025-
6/2025. IRs document Youth A showing verbal and
physically aggressive behavior to other youth, not following
directives, and destroying property. One IR dated 3/3/2025
states Youth A refused to go to school. Four IRs dated
3/25/25, 3/26/25, 3/27/25, and 4/5/25 document Youth A
refused an offered meal.
Analysis There are no rule violations established regarding these
allegations. There is no evidence to support staff fail to make
appropriate effort to wake Youth A for school.
Consultation:
It is recommended the facility implement a documented procedure
of proper documentation and reporting regarding school absences
to the school, parent/guardian, and primary case management
staff.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142
Section Health Services; policies and procedures
Description (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical, and dental, and behavioral
health care.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The youth has been at the facility since February 2025 and has
lost 30-40 pounds.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 6/24/2025.
Complainant did not provide any additional information.
Director was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 6/24/2025.
COO was also present via speakerphone. Director reported Youth
A entered the facility overweight and he has lost weight since
arrival. Director reported this is due to being active and stated
Youth A appears to be at a healthier weight. Director reported
there are items served Youth A does not like and when this occurs
6

if Youth A declines to eat what is served he is offered an
alternative. Director reported Youth A’s weight loss has not been a
concern of the doctor’s that he is aware of.
Case Manager was interviewed via telephone on 6/24/2025. Case
Manager denied having significant concerns regarding Youth A’s
care and safety in the facility. Case Manager reported Youth A
will decline eating what is served. However, Youth A did not state
to her why he declines the food at times. Case Manager denied
having concerns regarding Youth A getting enough to eat or his
weight loss stating Youth A appears healthy. Case Manager
denied Youth A expressing he is hungry or not getting enough to
eat.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/17/25.
Youth A gave a thumbs up when asked how he likes the food at
the facility. Youth A was observed to have a snack and eating it at
the time of the interview. Youth A reported sometimes he does not
eat what is served. Youth A did not remember if he is offered
something else or if he eats something else instead. Youth A
reported he is always hungry. Youth A reported he eats most of
what is served and will just throw away what he does not like.
Youth A was not able to say what he throws out or what he does
not like. Youth A reported if he tells someone he is hungry they
will offer him something to eat.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/17/25.
Youth B reported the food is okay at the facility and if they do not
like what is there they can get something else. Youth A reported
the facility gives snacks multiple times a day. Youth B denied
observing Youth A around mealtimes or knowing if he throws his
food away without eating it.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/17/25.
Staff 1 reported he will refuse meals at times and he is offered
something else. Staff 1 denied observing Youth A refuse both the
meal and the alternative when given to him. Staff 1 reported Youth
A has lost weight and looks healthy now. Staff 1 reported Youth A
was chunky when he arrived at the facility. Staff 1 denied hearing
Youth A complain of being hungry.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on 7/17/25.
Staff 2 denied Youth A complaining of hunger or not getting
enough to eat. Staff 2 reported she has observed Youth A decline
what is offered for dinner as well as the alternative and state he is
not hungry. Staff 2 reported Youth A will eat the snacks offered.
Documentation Reviewed:
7

• Incident Reports (19) regarding Youth A from 2/2025-
6/2025. IRs document Youth A showing verbal and
physically aggressive behavior to other youth, not following
directives, and destroying property. One IR dated 3/3/2025
states Youth A refused to go to school. Four IRs dated
3/25/25, 3/26/25, 3/27/25, and 4/5/25 document Youth A
refused an offered meal.
• Well Child Exam dated 11/25/2024 states Youth A is obese
at 185.4 pounds.
• Admission Health Screen for Youth A dated 2/14/2025
documents Youth A to weigh 188 lbs.
• Pediatrician Visit dated 4/7/2025 states Youth A weighs
168 lbs.
• Medication Review dated 7/23/2025 states Youth A weighs
151 lbs.
• Food Policy states youth are offered an alternative if they
do not like the meal offered. Food Policy states three meals
and two snacks are served to the youth at the facility each
day.
Analysis There are no rule violations established regarding these
allegations. There is no evidence the facility fails to meet Youth
A’s nutritional needs. Per medical documentation weight loss
occurred over time since arriving at the facility; this weight loss
was not raised as a concern by medical professionals completing
the evaluations.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
